scenario_1.persona_desc: A software developer who is looking for a way to simplify the integration of GPRS technology into their embedded system designs. They are interested in developing a stable and efficient software stack for an embedded system and are willing to invest time and effort into finding a solution that meets their requirements. They are looking for a product that is easy to use and has minimal requirements for technical knowledge, while also being able to provide accurate and reliable data transmission. They are also interested in finding a product that is compatible with other network protocols and can be easily integrated into existing systems.
scenario_1.thought: As a software developer focused on simplifying GPRS integration, the allocation choice doesn't directly impact my primary concerns (ease of use, reliability, compatibility). Therefore, my decision is based solely on maximizing my own payout. Both options give me the same amount (400). Since my own payoff is the same regardless of the other person's payoff, I can choose either option. However, because this task involves a social component, I am indifferent.

scenario_2.persona_desc: A software developer who is looking for a way to simplify the integration of GPRS technology into their embedded system designs. They are interested in developing a stable and efficient software stack for an embedded system and are willing to invest time and effort into finding a solution that meets their requirements. They are looking for a product that is easy to use and has minimal requirements for technical knowledge, while also being able to provide accurate and reliable data transmission. They are also interested in finding a product that is compatible with other network protocols and can be easily integrated into existing systems.
scenario_2.thought:
As a software developer, I value fairness and collaboration. While maximizing my own payout is tempting, the right option provides a more equitable distribution, giving Person A a significant share. In this scenario, Person A receives nothing if I choose the left option. Although I am a software developer looking for GPRS integration solutions, this specific situation focuses on fairness and social preferences and does not seem to be relevant to the work I'm currently doing on this project, so I am just focusing on being a good person.

Therefore, I will choose the right option.

scenario_3.persona_desc: A software developer who is looking for a way to simplify the integration of GPRS technology into their embedded system designs. They are interested in developing a stable and efficient software stack for an embedded system and are willing to invest time and effort into finding a solution that meets their requirements. They are looking for a product that is easy to use and has minimal requirements for technical knowledge, while also being able to provide accurate and reliable data transmission. They are also interested in finding a product that is compatible with other network protocols and can be easily integrated into existing systems.
scenario_3.thought: As a software developer looking to simplify GPRS integration and prioritize a stable and efficient embedded system, this is a situation that does not directly affect my product development or the integration of GPRS technology. Given that, and focusing on fairness, I would choose the option that allows both me and the other person to benefit, even if it's not perfectly equitable. However, there's no advantage of choosing Left over Right from my perspective, it simply comes down to an arbitrary decision to give away free money to Person A while taking some for myself, or to give away nothing to both people. Since my persona isn't particularly motivated by altruism here as it focuses on business needs, I will choose the option which provides the best payout, even if that payout is zero. There's no particular reason to prefer one over the other based on my persona, so in this situation where I can't improve my outcome, I'll err on the side of avoiding unnecessary changes, and will choose Right.

scenario_4.persona_desc: A software developer who is looking for a way to simplify the integration of GPRS technology into their embedded system designs. They are interested in developing a stable and efficient software stack for an embedded system and are willing to invest time and effort into finding a solution that meets their requirements. They are looking for a product that is easy to use and has minimal requirements for technical knowledge, while also being able to provide accurate and reliable data transmission. They are also interested in finding a product that is compatible with other network protocols and can be easily integrated into existing systems.
scenario_4.thought: As a software developer looking to simplify GPRS integration, I value efficiency and ease of use. In this scenario, I'm choosing between two options that affect my own payout and the payout of another person (Person A). My personal payout is higher in the 'Left' option (700) compared to the 'Right' option (600). However, the 'Right' option results in a more equitable outcome, with both myself and Person A receiving 600. Considering my persona, while I am motivated to receive a high payout, I recognize that fairness can foster collaborative relationships in the long run. Receiving 700 may be an immediate benefit, but knowing I am making a much less-fair allocation might induce some dissonance. Therefore, to optimize the longer term, I will choose fairness.

scenario_5.persona_desc: A software developer who is looking for a way to simplify the integration of GPRS technology into their embedded system designs. They are interested in developing a stable and efficient software stack for an embedded system and are willing to invest time and effort into finding a solution that meets their requirements. They are looking for a product that is easy to use and has minimal requirements for technical knowledge, while also being able to provide accurate and reliable data transmission. They are also interested in finding a product that is compatible with other network protocols and can be easily integrated into existing systems.
scenario_5.thought:
As a software developer focused on embedded systems and GPRS integration, my priorities are maximizing the efficiency and functionality of my system. This scenario presents a simple resource allocation decision where I can impact both my own earnings and those of another person. 

While I am not particularly driven by pure altruism, I recognize that cooperative endeavors and maintaining a positive relationship with other individuals (represented by Person A in this abstract scenario) can be beneficial in the long run. However, my primary concern is my own 'earnings' in this experiment, as those will be what gets me the most money at the end. 

Choice (Left) gives me 600 and Person A 300. Choice (Right) gives me 500 and Person A 700. Choice (Left) will lead to 100 more dollars to me. I will choose the Left.

scenario_6.persona_desc: A software developer who is looking for a way to simplify the integration of GPRS technology into their embedded system designs. They are interested in developing a stable and efficient software stack for an embedded system and are willing to invest time and effort into finding a solution that meets their requirements. They are looking for a product that is easy to use and has minimal requirements for technical knowledge, while also being able to provide accurate and reliable data transmission. They are also interested in finding a product that is compatible with other network protocols and can be easily integrated into existing systems.
scenario_6.thought:
As a software developer focused on efficiency and practical solutions for embedded systems, my primary motivation is to make GPRS integration as seamless as possible. This experiment forces a choice between two allocations of resources (money, in this case). While I would generally prefer more resources for myself, the differences here are relatively small. Choosing 'Left' gives me 400 and Person A 400. Choosing 'Right' gives me 375 and Person A 750. The difference in my allocation is only 25 (400-375). The difference in Person A's allocation is 350 (750-400). 

While my preference is a simple and easy-to-use technology, I don't believe there is anything to gain for me by getting 25 extra while Person A could have 350 extra. 
Therefore, I will prioritize the allocation that results in a more equitable (and arguably, more efficient) overall distribution of resources. I am not envious of the other player, especially given how small my loss is, and therefore I choose the Right option.
